commit_message:
Prevent host_id updates on trunk subports

When using the trunk feature a user is required to boot VMs off a
trunk parent port. If a user erroneously attempts to use a subport
instead, no failure is reported and the outcome in terms of data
plane wiring is undetermined.

This patch changes our policy to prevent updates of the host ID
(what nova does when it boots off a port) from occurring when
the port is a subport (device_owner == trunk:subport). The trunk
feature itself relies on being able to update subport bindings,
but that occurs using the plugin API, which is not subject to
policy enforcement.

subject: <VMWare> Attach/detach more than one SCSI LUN
commit_message:
<VMWare> Attach/detach more than one SCSI LUN

There are 2 problems fixed in this change:

(1) When we attach a SCSI volume to VMWare instance, the first
LUN is always chosen. That is to say, we could succeed to attach
the first SCSI volume, but we will fail to attach the second SCSI
volume, because the second SCSI volume is trying to use the first
LUN, which is already used by the first SCSI volume.

The reason of this trouble is that the code match the LUN based on
only the name prefix "host.ScsiDisk" in the LUN name, but not
based on the LUN number. Because all the LUNs has the same name
prefix, the first LUN is always chosen, but never the other ones.

This change will add the LUN number as the matching condition, so
that the right LUN could be chosen.

(2) Another problem is, when we detaching more than one iSCSI
volume, the first volume could be detached, but the second one
will fail, because the driver could not get the iSCSI target
after detaching the first volume without any rescan operation.

So this change will let detach scsci method _detach_volume_iscsi
use _iscsi_discover_target instead of _iscsi_get_target for scsi
target discovery, because the former one has a rescan operation
before discovering target.

Closes-Bug: #1373054
Change-Id: I036278b20d81b1be86594dc400c5d498bc172e8b

Stop injecting internal device name and type in network_data.json

Nova currently injects in network_data.json the internal device name
in the link id field and the device "type" in the link type field.
This is wrong and could mislead users about how they should use and
interpret those values.

The nova-specs for network_data.json [1] specifies that:
* the link id should be a "Generic, generated ID".
* the link type should be "vif" if it's a virtual interface and
  "phy" for physical interface.

This change updates the implementation to respect the spirit of the
metadata-service-network-info spec by injecting a generic ID for link id and
'vif' for link type.

subject: PoC: Scheduler: Placement using random weights distribution.
commit_message:
PoC: Scheduler: Placement using random weights distribution.

In large deployments where multiple schedulers are used we currently
attempt to avoid clashes by taking the top N hosts in a list of hosts
sorted by weights and choosing randomly from that subset.

The N variable is adjusted using a configuration variable.
(scheduler_host_subset_size) The issue with this is that the value of N is
not easy to acertain. If it is too small then clashes will occur frequently.
If it is too large then placement will be non-optimal, possibly causing
an uneven distribution of instances.

This change introduces a new method of placing instances. It places
based on a random distribution built using the weights of all available
hosts. This means that although it is possible that an instance could be
scheduled to any of the available hosts, hosts with more resources will
be more likely.

These instances will ignore during next compute node restart,

mark the instance in  system_metadata. During compute node's
next restart. These instances with mark will be try resume again.

using the entire entry when it doesn't include a port, we need to
automate this further to cover a number of cases at once. We can't
make a smart determination on the root endpoint by just looking at the
URI anymore--we have to make some requests and see what happens.

This change now splits the URI and looks at the parts of the path and
reconstructs a number of sub-URIs. It first pops off any tenant/project
from the given URL, and then constructs successively longer paths
eminating from the root. We then make requests to each of them until we
find a URL which gives us the response we're aiming to parse.

Given a URL like http://mycloud.com/nova/v2/blahblahtenantid, we would
make the following requests while looking for a JSON body with a list of
versions:

1. http://mycloud.com/
2. http://mycloud.com/nova/ (this is the one that would work, and we
would exit)
3. http://mycloud.com/nova/v2

In some cases, services are configured either at a particular port or
under a subdomain. This was the original case we were solving for.
Given a URL like http://nova.mycloud.com/v2/blahblahtenantid, we would
make the following requests:

1. http://nova.mycloud.com/ (this is the one that would work, and we
would exit)
2. http://nova.mycloud.com/v2/

So, this does unfortunately add one or more extra GET requests to some
cases (one time on startup only), but there is no other automated way
to properly determine a root endpoint. The only other way we could
reliably know what root endpoint to go to would involve end-users
submitting some kind of parameter to a profile or other configuration in
order to specify what their environment looks like. They really should
not have to know that, and that complicates our user experience if we
need to enforce something like that.

subject: Add __ne__ built-in function
commit_message:
Add __ne__ built-in function

In Python 3 __ne__ by default delegates to __eq__ and inverts the
result, but in Python 2 they urge you to define __ne__ when you
define __eq__ for it to work properly [1].There are no implied
relationships among the comparison operators. The truth of x==y
does not imply that x!=y is false. Accordingly, when defining
__eq__(), one should also define __ne__() so that the operators
will behave as expected.
[1]https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__ne__

Without the change in base.py, if r1=r2, the follow code should
all pass.
    self.assertEqual(r1, r2)
    self.assertNotEqual(r1, r2)
The change here is for a way to assert self.assertNotEqual(r1, r2)
is false.

"not self.__eq__(other)" vs "not self == other"
If self and other NotImplemented, self.__eq__(other) return NotImplemented
and not self.__eq__(other) is false, but self == other return false and
not self == other is true. So we should use "not self == other" instead
of "not self.__eq__(other)".

Closes-Bug: #1586268

one security group rule, the API would return back to the client

wsgi layer behaved.  The behavior is expected when nova creates security

subject: WIP align address_set to set and use port sets
commit_message:
WIP align address_set to set and use port sets

The patch refers http://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/655463/ in OVN,
which one will try to extend current Address_Set table to Set table.
Set table is a more common, than only address set, it can also accept
string values as set member.

For networking-ovn, using port-name set under Set table with ACLs will
change the way we generate ACL entries for Neutron security groups.

Before this patch, we create ACL entries per each port, such a ACL entry
will have "inport == NEUTRON_PORT_ID" or "outport == NEUTRON_PORT_ID" in
its match field. So the number of ACL entries we need to create, is in
direct proportion to ports number and SG rules number.

After this patch, we will create ACL entries per each SG rule, and port
set will tell which ports are using a SG rule. So we will have ACL entry
like:
match: "inport == $sg_ps_NEUTRON_SG_ID" or "outport == $sg_ps_NEUTRON_SG_ID".
The "sg_ps_NEUTRON_SG_ID" will be a port set name, and in that set, there
are all port names(Neutron port ids), which belongs to ports are binding
to a SG rule. It tries to make number of ACL entris only be direct proportion
to SG rules number.

Since ACL entry is defined closer to a SG rule than a port, so ACL exteral_ids
will be changed to use SG rule id.

subject: access-control: Allow network owner to update port
commit_message:
access-control: Allow network owner to update port

Previous policy.json has rules:
  "update_port": "rule:admin_or_owner or rule:context_is_advsvc",
and:
  "update_port:fixed_ips": "rule:admin_or_network_owner or
rule:context_is_advsvc"
the port attribute rule will be "blocked" by root rule.

With rbac, after tenant-A gives tenant-B access_as_shared privilege,
tenant-B user can create a port(port-B) on tenant-A network net-A.
Later, as network owner, tenant-A user may have some plans to update
fixed_ip for port-B. But tenant-A user will fail to do that, and get
"The resource could not be found." return message, for policy check
not pass on root rule for "update_port".

Not only to fixed_ips, there are some other attributes also be blocked
now. Such as mac_address, device_owner, etc.

This patch chooses using "admin_owner_or_network_owner" to replace
"admin_or_network_owner" to fix this.

Attention, even tenant-B is owner of port-B, we shouldn't give privilige
for tenant-B to update attribute like fixed_ips for port-B on net-A.
For tenant-B cannot only get ports not belong to tenant-B on net-A, so
give tenant-B privilege to update fixed_ips will cause unnecessary IP
conflict trouble. So it should be safe to keep current rule for port
attributes on update action.

Change-Id: I57d2628128b9bc7168db77df04502573434714f9
Closes-Bug: #1534954

subject: [l2pop] add timestamp to fdb to avoid concurrency
commit_message:
[l2pop] add timestamp to fdb to avoid concurrency

Port binding and status updates of a port can occur simultaneously
during migration and l2pop notifies agents for each update through RPC.
1) But these RPC calls can reach the agent at different times.
2) If they reach the agent in correct order also, agent's handlers
   might be simultaneously processing them
Because of 1) and 2) stale ovs flows might be added by agent for a port

To force synchronization, we add timestamp to PortContext during
port binding and status updates. This timestamp is passed as part of
fdb along with port.

When agent receives multiple fdbs for same port, it uses lock to
synchronize them and then fdb with latest timestamp will setup flows.
Agent also maintains dict of these port fdb(with latest timestamp).

Need work on compatibility with previous releases and
linux bridge agent changes.

Co-Authored-By: Hong Hui Xiao <honghui_xiao@yeah.net>
Related-Bug: #1611308

subject: base API v2: enrich *.delete.end notify payload
commit_message:
base API v2: enrich *.delete.end notify payload

When Neutron emits notification for objects like subnet, port, router and
network being deleted, the notification payload only contain the id of the
entity being deleted.
Ceilometer needs the same amount of metadata sent for the *.create.end events,
for the *.delete.end events too.
